sen.j: 辻占（つじうら）とは、日本で行われた占いの一種である。
sen.e: Tsujiura is a kind of fortune-telling which was done in Japan.
Tsujiura is a kind of fortune-telling seen in Japan.
Tsujiura is a kind of fortune-telling seen in Japan.

sen.j: 元々の辻占は、夕方に辻（交叉点）に立って、通りすがりの人々が話す言葉の内容を元に占うものであった。
sen.e: Originally it was fortune-telling based on the contents of words told by passer-bys and conducted by a person standing at a tsuji (intersection) in the evening.
Originally it was conducted by a fortune-teller standing at a tsuji (intersection) in the evening based on what passers-by talked.

sen.e: Originally it was conducted by a fortune-teller standing at a tsuji (intersection) in the evening based on what passers-by talked.

sen.j: この辻占は万葉集などの古典にも登場する。
sen.e: The tsujiura appears in classic literature such as "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves).

sen.j: 類似のものに、橋のたもとに立って占う橋占（はしうら）がある。
sen.e: There is a similar one called hashiura (bridge fortune-telling) which was done at the foot of a bridge.

sen.j: 夕方に行うことから夕占（ゆうけ）とも言う。
sen.e: It is also called yuke (evening fortune-telling) as it was done in the evening.

sen.j: 偶然そこを通った人々の言葉を、神 (神道)の託宣と考えたのである。
sen.e: They thought the accidental passer-bys' words as oracles of gods (Shintoism).
They thought the words of accidental passers-by as oracles of gods (Shintoism).

sen.j: 辻は人だけでなく神も通る場所であり、橋は異界との境をなすと考えられていた。
sen.e: They thought that the tsuji is a point where not only humans, but also gods passed by and that the bridge was a border to the different world.

sen.j: 京都・一条堀川の戻橋は橋占の名所でもあった。
sen.e: The Modori-bashi Bridge at Ichijo, Kyoto City was a famous spot for hashiura.
The Modori-bashi Bridge at Ichijo-Horikawa, Kyoto City was a famous spot for hashiura.

sen.j: 大阪府東大阪市の瓢箪山稲荷神社で今も行われる辻占は、通りすがりの人の言葉ではなく、その人の性別・服装・持物、同行の人の有無、その人が向かった方角などから吉凶を判断する。
sen.e: The tsujiura practiced even now at Hyoutanyama-Inari Shrine, Higashi Osaka City, Osaka Prefecture judges fortunes not based on a passer-by's words, but based on his sex, constume, belongings, whether accompanied or not, and the direction which he took.

sen.j: まず御籤で1～3の数字を出し、鳥居の前に立って、例えば御籤で2が出れば2番目に通った人の姿などを記録する。
sen.e: The person who wants to receive this service first draws Omikuji (sacred lots) to pick up a number from one to three, then stands in front of Torii, where, for example, if the number is two, then he records the appearance and other things of the second passer-by.

sen.j: その内容を元に宮司が神意を伺うのである。
sen.e: On the base of the contents of what he recorded, the providence is sought by the Guji (chief of those who serve a shrine, control festivals and general affairs).

sen.j: 江戸時代には、辻に子供が立っておみくじ（これも一種の占いである）を売るようになり、これも辻占と呼んだ。
sen.e: In the Edo period, children began to sell omikuji (sacred lots)(which is also a kind of fortune-telling) standing at a tsuji, and that was also called tsujiura.

sen.j: さらに、辻占で売られるような御籤を煎餅に入れた辻占煎餅（フォーチュン・クッキーはここから派生したもの）が作られ、これのことも辻占と呼んだ。
sen.e: Furthermore, tsujiura-senbei (from which fortune cookies were derived), which were made by inserting omikuji similar to those sold for tsujiura into senbei (rice crackers), were also called tsujiura.

sen.j: 石川県の金沢市には正月に色とりどりの辻占煎餅を、縁起物として家族で楽しむ風習があり、現在も和菓子店における辻占の製作風景は、年末恒例の風物詩となっている。
sen.e: In Kanazawa City, Ishikawa Prefecture, there is a custom that the whole family enjoy colorful tsujiura-senbei as good lucky charms, and even now the scene of tsujiura production in Japanese sweets shops is a special feature at the year end.
